And therefore, whereas thou O Solomon, received'st but five parts of the increase of thy Vineyard, how fruitful soever it be, and are fain to allow a sixth part thereof to them that dress and keep it; the whole profit and fruit that my Vineyard, (my Church) doth yeild, redoundeth wholly to my Self; and my Servants that labour in it, work not for themselves, but Me alone.

Ver. 13. Thou that dwellest in the Gardens, the Companions hearken to to thy Voyce, cause me to hear it] q. d. O my dear Church and Spouse, who hast thy chief aboad, and art most seen in the Assemblies, where my people meet together to worship me, which both for the pleasantness and fruitfulness, are like to the choicest and sweetest Gardens; all the faithful
which have a most near communion with me, and among themselves, will hearken unto thy voyce and ministry; let me by their prayers and praises, and holy confessions they make of my truth, wherein thou hast instructed them, hear and discern that they have indeed hearkened unto thee; for therein shall I take great comfort and delight.

Ver. 14. Make hast my Beloved, and be thou like to a Roe, or to a young Hart upon the Mountains of Spices] q. d. O my dear Lord and Saviour, do thou soon finish these days of sin and misery, and be thou like the Roe or young Hart in thy speed in comeing to judgment, and gathering together all thine Elect, to take them with thee into thy Kingdom, which as it is fitly compared unto a Mountain, because it is in the highest Heavens, so may it be called a Mountain of Spices, because there shall be fulness of joy and pleasures for ever more.

lg.head: Verse 1.
lg.l: THe Song of Songs, which is Solomons.

lg.head: Ver. 2.
lg.l: O let him joyn his lips to mine,

lg.head: Ver. 3.
lg.l: The savour thy good Oyntments shed;

lg.head: Ver. 4.
lg.l: Draw me, we will run after thee:
Me hath the King (where I would be)
Thus made glad, wee'l rejoyce therein,
We will remember more than wine:

lg.head: Ver. 5.
lg.l: Thus both as Ismaels Tents I seem,

lg.head: Ver. 6.
lg.l: Look not upon me, cease to gaze,
Now we so black you see;
Because the Sun, with scorching rayes,
Me keeper of the Vineyards made;

lg.head: Ver. 7.
lg.l: My Dearest, unto me make known,
Where thou dost feed thy Flock.
Where thou dost make them rest at noon'
By what cool stream or rock,)
Lest I should be as one of them,
Their Flocks, which thy Companions seem,

lg.head: Ver. 8.
lg.l: O thou, whose beauty doth excell
If this, because thou can'st not tell,
Go forth, and in those foot-steps tread,
And thou thy Kids securely feed,

lg.head: Ver. 9.
lg.l: My Love, I have compared thee
Which in King Pharoahs Charots be,

lg.head: Ver. 10.
lg.l: Thy Cheeks are comely, and thy Neck,
Those, with these rows of Jewels deckt,
This, with that chaine of Gold.

lg.head: Ver. 11.
lg.l: Borders of gold will we bestow,

lg.head: Ver. 12.
lg.l: My Spikenard, while the King doth sit,
At his full Table, then of it,

lg.head: Ver. 13.
lg.l: Hee'st lye betwixt my breasts, and there

lg.head: Ver. 14.
lg.l: As those, which in those Vineyards grow,

lg.head: Ver. 15.
lg.l: Behold thou'rt very fair my Love,
Thou by thine eyes, might'st be a Dove,

lg.head: Ver 16.
lg.l: In thee, and there are seen:
Behold thou'rt faire, and pleasant too;

lg.head: Ver. 17.
lg.l: The beams, which o're our house are laid,
Are all of goodly Cedar made;

lg.head: Ver. 1.
lg.l: A Rose, when it doth freshly blow,
The Lillie of the Valley too,

lg.head: Ver. 2.
lg.l: And as the Lillies to the briers,
So my fair Love, when she appears

lg.head: Ver. 3.
lg.l: Soe's my Beloved, such is he,
Under his shaddow I sat down,

lg.head: Ver. 4.
lg.l: He brought me to his Banquet-house,
And love, was over me, his Spouse,

lg.head: Ver. 5.
lg.l: Stay me with Flagons, stay me soon,
These fainting fits, or ere I swoon,
For I am sick of Love.

lg.head: Ver. 6.
lg.l: Under my head, when I take rest,
He doth his left hand place;
And with his right hand o're my breast,

lg.head: Ver. 7.
lg.l: I, by the Rose, and Hind,
Adjure you, and by all of them,
The fields have of their kind,
Now my Beloved takes his ease,
Nor stir him up, until he please,

lg.head: Ver. 9.
lg.l: Like a swift Roe is my Belov'd,
Like a young Hart he is;
Loe he behind our wall remov'd,

lg.head: Ver. 10.
lg.l: To me then my Beloved spake,
Rise up and do not stay;
'Tis time to rise, my Love; awake,

lg.head: Ver. 11.
lg.l: For loe, the Winter now is past,
The threatning rains (which fell so fast)

lg.head: Ver. 12.
lg.l: The flourie spring adorns the Earth,
The Turtles ('tis a time of mirth)

lg.head: Ver. 13.
lg.l: Fig-trees put forth green Figgs, likewise
Smell; O how sweet, my Love, Arise,
